comments.commentBody: The mindless media is always ready to dismiss any evolution of thinking as a flip flop.

There is nothing wrong with learning new information and modifying a position as a result.  The test is whether the person then sticks to that new position.  If that person just keeps flipping back and forth depending on who he is talking to that day, that has nothing to do with "learning", it is just pandering.  And that is exactly what Paul has been doing on the subject of foreign policy.  He is an anti-interventionist when talking to other anti-interventionists; he is a hawk when with other hawks.

It is interesting to me how many people say that Rand Paul's flipping is a "maturing process." He has changed his positions on issues so many times that one needs an abacus to keep count.

Most people mature at about the same rate. Ask yourself how many time you, yourself, have changed your position on most important issues. Daily? Weekly? Monthly? When the newest poll comes out?

All I know is I want to vote for someone for president who is already a grown up, completely mature, intelligent, and smart enough to realize that there are real problems in this country that need - and require - real solutions.

Kiddies should stay home (or in the large Washington, D. C. day care center called Congress).

I am  not a Republican nor a Paul disciple.  But I don't think "flip flopping" is a bad thing.  As we grow and learn, we may discover new information that was previously unavailable or unknown to us, leading to a change in viewpoint.  Certainly, a politician can change his or her point of view for less than honorable reasons, however, keeping an open mind demonstrates wisdom, something sorely lacking in the majority of our politicians.  I wish more of our politicians were brave or thoughtful enough to understand differing points of view rather than remain steadfast in their ignorance.

Being a non-member of your big white "we", I feal I should point out that:

A. Not everyone reading your comments are bound to be white, as you seem to assume;

B. Your sanctimonious grassroots-ism belies your own high self-regard and disconnection from the "facts on the ground". Unfortunately, social change often happens in so many terribly mundane everyday commitments, that have nothing to do with the quasi-revolutionary language you're using - it often has nothing to do with DEMANDING change from some higher power or catchy phrases (Moral Mondays!) but rather, ENACTING change oneself, no matter how dispiriting and terribly unrewarding it can be on a day-to-day basis. Until this reality is acknowledged, paper dragons masquerading as social change, will rule the day.

C. Again, let me state, I am not a member of the "you and I" club, and I have to express how terribly privileged and patronizing your language sounds to the non-white. I know you mean well, but please try to look deep inside yourself before putting yourself out there as the great white saint.

Barbara, read Rima again.  There is no blame.  You are too defensive.  No one is concluding that you are to blame.  Only you are inferring that.  Why, I don't know.  But this is about the present and the future, and realizing that we do have responsibity for the world, and country we make TODAY and TOMORROW, and for that reason, fighting for what's fair, and against what's not in the present. It doesn't matter whose to blame for the past, and who isn't, when you understand this.

Barbara, maybe you are completely guiltless.  But 9 out of 10 whites make the same argument you make.  But don't you think you have a duty to try to change society and make it fairer even if you don't ever discriminate?  Certainly you can work to see that policies are enacted that work against ageism and sexism.  In fact I bet you do. Why not work for similar policies against continuing racial discrimination? You don't have to feel guilty to do this any more than you have to feel guilty for being a woman or an older person.

While I agree that racism still exists and is very damaging, I find it hard to take the blame for it.  I don't hate people of other races.  I try to treat everyone with respect.  I am not powerful and don't have a company that can hire anyone, of any race or ethnicity.  What, exactly, as an individual, am I expected to do about this situation?  Feeling guilty does not accomplish anything. I have experienced sexism and ageism.  I don't blame everyone for these biases, just the people who have them and use them against others.  I remember Spike Lee saying in an interview that he made the movie "Malcolm X" because no white people had read the book.  I read it (I am white) when I was a young women, the year it came out.  Who was the biased one, Spike Lee or me?

For me, it happened by chance. My mother's health declined when my kids were fairly young. I'm a chef, and my wife a dentist. We live frugally, and could make it on one salary...just not mine. My wife has never been resentful for a moment, and I was very active at school-PTA, committees, even teaching a cooking class/desktop publishing a cookbook in the gifted and talented program, which I did for five years. I was a chaperone on dozens of class trips.
I was able to manage my mother's care for the last seven years of her life, and see my kids through college trips, applications and move-ins and outs. I never had doubts, and I never got flak from mothers around school or the swim teams my daughters were on. But maybe part of it was the thick skin from decades in professional kitchens makes one cultivate. It all worked out even if it wasn't planned.

I cannot count how many times I have been suspected of nefarious motives as a man relating, however briefly and innocently, even helpfully, to a child not my own. It happened to you in sunny Marin County; just imagine the social climate of New York!

My most striking memory in this regard involved my rescuing an unattended (and crying) toddler from the waves at Greenwich Point Park. Only as I was carrying the distraught child away from the water and toward the gaggle of cocktail-drinking moms whom I had guessed might know this child did I get their attention, attention that quickly turned to hostility and never subsided even when I explained that the child was alone in the water.

Men are not trusted around children. This needs to change.

The playground scene - did this ring a bell and a nasty one, too.

My daughter (now) 29 and I were at the playground which had a serious climbing structure of timbers, all very Marin County and hip.

Another little girl found herself stuck at a precipice, some five feet in the air, and started crying and screaming for help. I looked around - no mom in sight. I waited a while longer, got very concerned and helped the girl down, only to be confronted by her equally scared mom who called me several colorful names and threatened to call the police "if I ever touched her daughter again."

I thought my experience was unique (only dad at the playground) but after reading these letters, I realize it was not. Gee, I guess I should feel fortunate that I don't have a record - seriously!

BTW my daughter gave me a copy of "Dad's Own Cookbook," good stuff for you recipe swappers. I still use it. Add a touch of penne pasta to lentil soup. Wash it all down with a fresh fruit smoothie. Arugula salad, too.

--"political inaction and falling prices--will balance out,".....No, they will make each other worse. With inflation at 1.7% in the U.S., with the value of the dollar increasing significantly against other currencies, with high unemployment and stagnant wages, we should have been spending to rebuild our infrastructure yesterday. With a Republican Congress that is hopelessly wedded to supply side dogma, which is exactly the wrong approach under these economic circumstances, we will be lucky to avoid a depression.

I know white people who have suffered criminal penalties for drug use.  there are huge discrepancies in the criminal justice system, granted.  But please don't use absolutes such as "for white boys drug use results in a stern lecture…"  That is not always the case.

"...there is new research showing that the daughters of active fathers are healthier and have higher self-esteem..."

I wonder why the article mentions just daughters. What about sons? Are they healthier too, and do they too have higher self-esteem? Or do sons suffer under insecure fathers who seem to feel it necessary to establish their dominance and their "masculinity" at every moment, uncomfortable at feeding and cleaning up after boys who may eventually follow professional careers, uncomfortable at the thought that their boys may perceive them as less than masculine because of what they do?

We do know that many emotional problems faced by men as adults stem from their having had poor or no father figures in their childhood.

@ Mistr Knucklz

Very appropriate moniker.
Do they scrape the ground when you walk by these " fem-dads"?

Fem-dad? What's a fem-dad? Do you mean homosexual? Or do you mean, any man with a child strapped to his chest is a fem-dad? What if the mother is near by and just had back surgery and can't carry her child - is that dad still a fem-dad, or is he now he-dad, because he's doing the heavy lifting the little lady can't do?

Countless women have told me how attracted they are to a man caring for a child. Such behavior is a sexual turn-on linked to biologically-programmed mate selection.

As for your insulting remark about a child strapped to a man's chest, I guess you have never experienced the tender feeling of protecting a child, never experienced the bond that develops from this simple act.

The emasculation of American men has been taken to a new level.  For centuries, men have protected and provided for children, with women giving nurture and comfort.  Now the roles have been completely reversed.  Watching a fem-dad walk by with the kid strapped to his chest in a papoose is just sad.

The whole process selects out sane and rational people. Nobody in their right mind wants to spend two years reciting staff written talking points to crowds while not en route to the next gig dialling for dollars all the way.

By the time you get to write in Alex from Target there will be (another) clown car filled to the brim with Tonya from Target, Larry from Lowes and Sandy from Sears. Corporate affiliation is the next step in the influence game, dark money is becoming passe. Makers and sellers of various products and services will be scrambling to market their new, improved alliterative candidate du jour, the younger the better. Just like race car drivers or players at the world series of poker, these neophytes will be adorned with labels and logos of their sponsors and will star in the ads for them during commercial breaks during the debates. I can see the resurrection of the Dating Game or the Bachelorette, with Barbie draped in the American flag and Ken-like bobble head dolls of each pretender to the throne competing to see who wins the chance to despoil her for good. I can't wait to see the graphics accompanying the candidates from extractive industries, defense contractors and financial institutions. The ticker on the bottom of our screens will tally the thumbs on Facebook, comments on Twitter and the running Vegas line on each one's success. Vacuous but attractive newsreaders will make inane observations from anchor desks, then segue between reporters on the spot and commentators with practiced gravitas waffling about possibilities, probabilities and the vast unknowns. As we clamor to know whose shirts they wear, our Nation will circle the bowl, flush with anticipation.
If you could bottle them, they might sell as a sleeping aid.

If only Alex from Target were old enough to run for President…then all our problems would be solved. He's definitely a great character nonetheless.

But in any event, I'm not terribly impressed with the growing roster of presidential hopefuls coming from either side of the aisle. This country is experiencing more change than hope at the moment and we need a leader who has the energetic stance of a happy warrior coupled with impeccable ethics, savvy political skills, and true moral gravitas. It would also be great if this individual had prior experience governing something--a city, a state, a corporation, but preferably a governor or former governor.

I can't think of anyone qualified who would consider a run. And if there were someone and they decided to throw their hat in the ring, they would be outspent by Christie, Bush, or Clinton. Or Paul, Rubio, Cruz, Ryan or Walker.

And no, even though Scott Walker has real governing experience, he's not a great character.

Perhaps I'll write in Alex from Target.
That's not really what this article is about.

Really? Do you get comments from strangers when you are out with your children alone? Are you told "good luck" or "god bless YOU honey" just because your spouse isn't with you? Does your school automatically call your husband even though you said you should be the first called in an emergency?

I didn't think so. Watch how men are treated as fathers I this society compared to women. I am not a fan of anyone staying at home full time (I think it contributes to society making balance even harder for workers) but if you think fathers being active fathers aren't stigmatized in this society, you haven't been paying attention.

I'd love to see stay-at-home mothers so glorified.  I won't hold my breath waiting for that though. This mindset behind this article is the same as when a man cleans the bathroom ( or washes the dishes, does the laundry, mops the floor, etc), he's some kind of hero, worthy of accolades. When the woman does the same thing, eh, not so much much. This is a non-story.

I agree, but let's face it - at least from their perspective - these guys hit the jackpot. The women are obviously willing to permit them to stay home while they earn the money - at least at a certain level.

I do agree that the "male-as-provider" is biologically ingrained. I just can't imagine that their wives have respect for them.,

'Lessons for the euro zone??'

I will NOT support Argentina going on the Euro!
-(even if they beg)
Why the empty insult?
Beta Males. So cute.

My occupation--pediatrician--allows me the privilege of speaking to all kinds of families.  Some families have a mom and dad, some have a grandparent, some have two fathers or two mothers, and some have a dad that stays home and a mom who goes to work all day. One unifying theme for a happy and well adjusted child emerges over and over again: a "parent" that consistently provides unconditional love. It really is that simple.

Wood was important then.  Trees grow back, especially with an emergent US Forrest Service under Gifford Pinchot at the end of the 19th Century.  People do not.  To equate the two is a little silly.  Think of all the manpower and gene pool lost in the Civil War.  In fact, vast areas that had been cleared during almost 250 years of occupation, before the war, have grown back, in lands subject to the two armies and places such as the northeast that were not.  At Gettysburg, land is being cleared so that the historic battlefield can be viewed and studied as it was in July, 1963.  Yes, commercial buildings have been demolished, utility poles have been taken down, and new growth trees are cut down.  Yes, trees and crops can be replanted, but Grant and Sherman knew that the way to SAVE lives was to end the war ASAP, and that meant destruction of infrastructure, industry and crops in the confederate states.  Had the war been conducted as it had been up to late 1862, with sporadic battles fought along Napoleonic lines, it could have lasted indefinitely and consumed even more lives and natural bounty,

Wow! Some of these comments are rich! Trust me: women can still be wildly attracted to a SAHD! Good grief! What rock did you just crawl out from under? A good marriage is based on love, empathy, respect, and sharing the awesome responsibility/joy of raising youngsters. Does it really matter who is making the money and who is staying home caring for the house and children? Aren't husbands and wives partners? All Neanderthals - male and female alike who can only think and function in rigid roles - can now go back into their caves.

I suppose one question would be, why do you feel the need to be welcomed into women's groups? Really, why is this a pet grouse for so many stay-at-home dads? One must wonder if some of these dads were subconsciously hoping for this bonus when they embarked on this career.

Maybe those women just don't want the complication of a strange man in their women's group; a strange man talking freely to their kids; a strange man who may end up taking liberties with them even in the presence of their own spouses and affect their family relationships. It's nothing personal; they would have a whole host of very valid reasons for not welcoming any man into their group. Men should really be asking why they have so much difficulty in bonding closely with other men.

Luckily for their children, not a single one of these Men give 2 thoughts about how "embarrassed" you feel for them. I'd certainly hate to be the child of a father that allows "deeply entrenched" artifices of primeval instinct to prevent oneself from being a responsible, engaged caretaker.

"Biologically designed" is about as relevant and old fashioned as "hunting and gathering." People weren't "designed" at all, and certainly not for sitting in offices and working at computers all day. In your mind is working in some office somehow more "masculine" then staying at home and caring for children? That's a pretty depressing philosophy, and one I hope your children don't pick up from you.
Feel bad for them?... really? Welcome to 2014, where there's  more than one way to live a happy productive life.
M, what is it about this that threatens you?

As a woman, I have always opened my own jars and lifted my own heavy objects, thanks. I also repair my own car, fix my own plumbing, paint my own house, and make my own money. And my three daughters are being taught to do the same. Marriage is about support, not dependence. And your suggestion that women need men to be "manly" implies that they are incapable on their own.

Nothing makes life easier than sharing roles. There is nothing inherent in my biology that makes me a better parent than my husband, or me a lesser worker either.
Soon these "stay-at-home" fathers will need their wives help to open jars and lift heavy objects.

You should be embarrassed with your limited thinking. My wife and I made a choice based on the best thing for our family. Although it has not been easy, I am far from emasculated in fact I still have many fans including my wife!

The assumption that a parent is at home is bad for families in my opinion. Where we live, aftercare is the norm, sports and classes are on school campuses, etc. This is hugely helpful for maintaining balance with work and family for both parents.

No one should have to give up their career to shuttle a child to violin at 3:30.

As a college professor I was able to get a morning schedule that enabled me to pick up the kids in the afternoon at school so they could stay for clubs, teams and such.  Indeed, In the burbs transportation to sports fields, friend's homes etc. is significantly aided by a parent who is available in the afternoon.  Lots of latch-key kids without such transportation infrastructure miss out and are left to their own devices.

I think the fault in the author's reasoning is that Americans do care about their privacy. The problem is that if you want to do ANYTHING today, you have to submit to the demands of a relatively small cartel of communications and media empires. In other words, American consumers really have no choice in the matter and they have really no legal recourse (unlike in Europe where there are laws the specifically govern such things).

The truth is that the entire technological infrastructure has been basically usurped for twp things: spying and marketing. Every other form of innovation has been waylaid on the way to market so that billions can be spent for a lot of useless stuff that do not solve this generation's central challenges: nutritious food, clean water, disease control, climate change, energy infrastructure, financial stability and democracy.

I don't understand this sentiment at all.  Do you feel really bad and embarrassed for mothers who have full and rewarding careers outside the home?  What about for people who are confined to wheelchairs or otherwise experience life other than in the manner they were "biologically designed" to live it?

But why the front-runner designation in the first place? Because the GOP is intellectually bankrupt and has been for decades.  So the GOP will have candidate after candidate assume the front runner spot the next 18 or so months, but each will hang on only temporarily.  And when one of them finally wins the Presidential nomination, he will then have trouble choosing a suitable VP running mate.  As did McCain and Romney, the 2016 Presidential nominee will end up choosing the last VP candidate interviewed -- because he had already rejected all the prior interviewees and under the pressure of time, he will have no choice left but to reluctantly pick the last one he talked to.
